Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative: A Criminology-Based Simulation of Dynamic Adversarial Behavior in Cyberattacks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2016, the cyberthreat landscape showcased advanced attack techniques, escalated attack frequency, and high levels of adversarial sophistication. Conventional cyberattack management is response-driven, with organizations focusing their efforts on detecting threats, rather than anticipating adversarial actions. This reactive approach has limited efficacy, as it does not capture advanced and sophisticated adversaries, mutating or unknown malware, living-off-the-land techniques or new variants being deployed. There is thus an immediate need for a paradigm shift in the area of cybersecurity. Security experts are calling for anticipatory or proactive defense measures that focus on adversarial behavior and movement. This research aims to develop a criminological theory that captures the dynamics of cybercrime and a corresponding simulator to generate attack scenarios that adapts to ever changing and diverse cyber vulnerabilities, defense, and adversary tactics.

This research has two connected objectives: (1) Develop (and evaluate) an integrated Dynamic Routine Activities Theory (DRAT), which examines the continually changing interaction between offender, target, and guardian (OTG) along cyberattack trajectories aided by Monte-Carlo simulation; and (2) Understand how variations in OTG impact dynamic adversarial attack trajectories. Specifically, how can these variations and amounts of variations be measured, modeled and simulated, and what might these variations imply for DRAT -- Understanding adversarial attack trajectories, and how these can be disrupted to impact adversaries, will be instrumental in comprehending anticipatory cyber defense and ultimately contribute to the paradigm shift towards proactive cybersecurity. This exploratory, multidisciplinary research marries the two disciplines of criminology and computer engineering to push the research frontier on proactive cybersecurity. This groundbreaking intersection will generate new criminological theoretical knowledge, mixed-method innovations, and theoretically-informed simulation that prepare defenders with preemptive and comprehensive knowledge and tools in facing adaptive and sophisticated adversaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project aims to understand, model, and simulate cyber adversary behavior through interdisciplinary analysis of both in-person observations and intrusion logs collected through cybersecurity exercises. PI Yang from Rochester Institute of Technology and PI Rege from Temple University collaborated in collecting and analyzing observables through Collegiate Penetration Testing Competitions (CPTC) in 2017, 2018, and 2019 (nationalcptc.org) hosted at RIT. Over the three-year project period, PI Yang's group has developed the following main scientific and technological advances:

An Attack Intent Stage (AIS) model to describe the intended outcome of an observed cyberattack action. The AIS is developed by reference to various attack kill chains and MITRE's ATT&CK framework. The final version of AIS provides: a) observability through intrusion alerts, b) interpretability for adversary intended action outcomes, c) compatibility to industry standards, and d) usability for machine learning algorithms.

A transfer learning approach to automatic translate Suricata intrusion alerts into AIS. The approach leverages various open-domain cybersecurity descriptions, including MITRE's ATT&CK framework description and NVD database, to translate the short and often cryptic intrusion alert description into interpretable categorical AIS.

A Gaussian smoothing algorithm to produce attack episodes by processing large volume and continuous arriving intrusion alerts interpreted through AIS. These attack episodes provide an interpretable series of intended outcomes by the cyberattackers, and offer a means to compare them to the in-person observations collected by PI Rege's team.

A set of visualization modules that facilitate researchers to assess and compare attack behaviors over time and across CPTC teams. Translating intrusion alerts into AIS and attack episodes is not easily interpretable by researchers across disciplines. PI Yang's team has developed a temporal and a spatial attack feature plots to help visualize the AIS, port-service, and other features.

The use of Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) to learn the attack ferature dependencies exhibited in the intrusion alerts. Understanding these dependencies helps interpret the attacker behaviors exhibited by each CPTC team.

A preliminary session-based cyberattack simulator based on AIS. PI Yang's team further collaborates with an international researcher to demonstrate the ability to simulate cyberattacks under various conditions by referencing to AIS.

The above advances have helped facilitate the interdisciplinary analysis of data collected through CPTC. Several findings were published in various venues. One example of the interdisciplinary findings is that the time spent for different attack stages are significantly different from what the volume of intrusion alerts indicates. This is not unexpected because actions such as port scans take little time to prepare but generate a large amount of intrusion alerts, while a specific exploit takes time to prepare and generates very few intrusion alerts (or no alerts in some cases). We confirmed that cyberattack progressions through attack stages based on both in-person observations and intrusion alerts collected. Each penetration team often repeats several cycles of partial attack kill chains in a competition. In fact, the attack progression is really not a "chain"; rather, attackers and penetration teams as a while move quite freely between most attack stages. This observation has led to several additional research questions that are being investigated by PI Yang's research team.

This project has directly and indirectly involved a number of students, researchers, and practitioners, who gained significant experiences in interdisciplinary collaborations across criminal justice, cybersecurity, and computer engineering. Through our collaborations with the CPTC organizers, this project has helped influence RIT's decision to expand the infrastructure capital to host regional, national, and international CPTC annually with a formal data collection process. Students and practitioners beyond the project have been exposed to our interdisciplinary effort and many participated in our study. Other researchers across disciplines, including software engineering and psychology, have also modeled after our project to conduct their studies through CPTC.

In addition to its direct impact to the project objectives, the research advances have extended influence to several other collaborative projects of PI Yang's group. Specifically, the AIS model has been adopted in projects with OmniSOC and CARC at Indiana University, with Masaryk University in Czech Republic, and with TU Delft in Netherlands. Such collaborations have enhanced both researcher's and practitioner's exposure in an interdisciplinary thinking of translating cyber adversary actions into attack intent stages.

This interdisciplinary exploratory research has paved a pathway towards effective analysis of intrusion observables to better understand the intended outcomes of cyber adversary. Such understanding, including the limitations on what cannot be observed through intrusion alerts, offers insights to the broader society on the critical importance for interdisciplinary studies and dialog, to truly appreciate and understand the limitations of technologies. Meanwhile, communicating technology advances to social scientists and practitioners effectively are equally important to enhance social science methodologies.
